rev.comment: that is not a "wekeness" of open standards by any stretch, the only way to prevent the issue is to have regulation and/or informed users
rev.diff:
Line 101: Line 101:
==Avoiding vendor lock-in for computer software==
==Avoiding vendor lock-in for computer software==
â
In the 1980s and 1990s, public, royalty-free [[standardization|standard]]s were hailed as the best solution to vendor lock-in. The weakness of such standards was that if one software vendor achieved a dominant market share, "[[embrace, extend and extinguish]]" (EEE) tactics could be used to render the standard obsolete. The history of [[SQL]] is an archetypical example.
+
In the 1980s and 1990s, public, royalty-free [[standardization|standard]]s were hailed as the best solution to vendor lock-in. But there is still a possibility that one software vendor uses "[[embrace, extend and extinguish]]" (EEE) tactics to achieves a dominant market share, which could render the standard obsolete. The history of [[SQL]] is an archetypical example.
Since the late 1990s, the use of [[free and open source software]] (FOSS) has arisen as a stronger solution. Because FOSS can be modified and distributed by anyone, the availability of functionality usually cannot tie a user to one distributor. The ineffectiveness of distributor lock-in means there's no incentive for FOSS developers to invent redundant new data formats if usable (royalty-free) standards exist.
Since the late 1990s, the use of [[free and open source software]] (FOSS) has arisen as a stronger solution. Because FOSS can be modified and distributed by anyone, the availability of functionality usually cannot tie a user to one distributor. The ineffectiveness of distributor lock-in means there's no incentive for FOSS developers to invent redundant new data formats if usable (royalty-free) standards exist.
